BATTERY PARK Music Hot and Cool For Summer Lunch Hours
The Alliance for Downtown New York has put together an eclectic music mix for Wednesday lunch hours this summer.

From Latin to jazz to Dixieland, the performers, in order of appearance starting June 21, are: Lanham and O'Connor, Linda Ipanema and the Dixiecats, Bob Cantwell and the Stompers, the String of Pearls, Mike Carubia and the Great Southern Jazz Band, Harlem Renaissance Orchestra, Shade Tree Mechanics, Bubbles Band with the Hawaiian Express Dancers, Sue Halloran Quartet, Joe Battaglia and the New York Big Band and the Latin Jazz Band.
Summer Concert Series, Wednesdays 12:15 to 1:45, June 21 through Aug. 30; 1 Battery Park Plaza; free; (212) 407-2429.
RED HOOK Waterfront Rocks By Land and Sea

A 10 a.m. breakfast this Saturday at Harold Ickes Park (Hamilton and Van Brunt Streets) is the beginning of the all-day Red Hook Waterfront Arts Celebration 2000. An earth and surf parade, with David Pleasant's Blue Riddim Society, a percussion band, will wind up at the Beard Street Pier by noon.

Live music, dance and more food will precede the sixth annual Young People's Performance Festival, produced by Dancing in the Streets. In two sets of four, one at 1 p.m., the second at 3:30 p.m., students will do step dance, tap, hip hop or combinations of international dance. The Little Rhythm Kings, from last year's festival, are pictured below.

Between the performances, the Manhattan Samba band will play and there will be workshops in face painting, caricature, juggling and step dancing. At 4:30, the group will head to the Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge at Pier 45 (Conover Street) for music and an aquatic performance until sunset.
''Red Hook Waterfront Arts Celebration 2000,'' Saturday 10 a.m. to sunset; free; (212) 625-3505 for Dancing in the Streets or (718) 624-4719 for the Waterfront Museum or parade information.
GRAND ARMY PLAZA Crowning King, Queen And Marble Players

''It's not easy being king,'' said the comedian Jerry Stiller, who will be crowned homecoming king, as his wife, the actress Anne Meara (above right, with her husband), is named queen at the Welcome Back to Brooklyn Homecoming Festival at the Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn today. ''But it's a great honor.''

Before the induction at 2 p.m., players will be sought to help break the record (569) for the most people playing marbles at the same time; 50 playing circles will be chalked on the asphalt at Grand Army Plaza to allow for more than 1,000 players.
''Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival,'' today; noon to 6 p.m.; Grand Army Plaza; junction of Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway; free; (718) 855-7882, ext. 46.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

ART FORUM: A forum for writers and visual artists to share experiences and discuss society's influence on art will be held by African Voices magazine on Saturday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Harlem State Office Building, 163 West 125th Street, second floor; $20 in advance or $25 at the door; includes a one-year subscription to the magazine; (212) 865-2982.

FISH ARE JUMPING: You don't have to travel to the Adirondacks to fish for largemouth bass, pumpkinseed or bluegill. You can take a fishing pole and bread dough for bait to Baisley Pond Park in Queens for a fishing contest; 1 p.m. today; meet park rangers at Baisley Boulevard and 155th Street; free; (718) 846-2731.

DANCE OR JUST WATCH: Seventy dancers from New York City public schools will foxtrot, merengue, tango, rumba and swing in a competition at the World Financial Center Winter Garden; Wednesday, 5:30 to 6 p.m.; the public is invited to dance from 5 to 5:30 p.m. and from 6 to 6:30 p.m.; Battery Park City on West Street between Vesey and Liberty Streets; free; (212) 945-0505.
ALLISON FASS and LIZ MURRAY
